H0.text: The unique characteristic of water's specific heat is that it can only be measured in calories.

H1.text: Water's specific heat is lower than that of other common substances.

H2.text: The specific heat of water is higher than other common substances.

H3.text: Requires little energy for a big temperature change is a unique characteristic of water's specific heat.

A4.text: Water has a very high specific heat capacity of 4184 J/(kg·K) at 20 °C, the second-highest among heteroatomic species after ammonia.

A5.text: These properties allow water to moderate Earth's climate by buffering large fluctuations in temperature.
